title: Russell Museum opens new photography exhibit
text:
Russell Museum opens new photography exhibit Traci Rosenbaum, trosenbaum@greatfallstribune.com 8:01 p.m. MDT October 1, 2015 A mountain goat walks a rocky ridge. Glacier National Park, Montana. (Photo: COURTESY PHOTO/STEVEN GNAM) Saturday, Oct. 15 from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. C.M. Russell Museum 3 CONNECT 13 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Don’t let the name fool you. The C.M. Russell Museum offers more than just cowboy art. On Oct. 15, the public is invited to the opening of the museum’s new exhibition featuring photography by Steven Gnam. 
Gnam’s exhibition, “Crown of the Continent: The Wildest Rockies,” features 40 photographs of the Rocky Mountains, including the wildlands, wildlife and people of the North American West. His book of the same title has been nominated for several awards. 
To celebrate the opening, the museum features family-friendly tours at 10:30 a.m., 11:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m. and encourages guests to create a project inspired by their visit. 
Comprised of photographs and maps illustrating the Crown of the Continent's ecosystem, Gnam’s photography explores connections between culture, history, communities and the outdoors. This exhibition is a continuation of the museum’s Wildlife Art Initiative, an effort to share wildlife and nature scenes as depicted in the artwork of the American West. 
Always carrying his camera, Gnam runs, hikes, swims, climbs and skis through the landscape in order to find his photographs. His work has been featured by everyone from National Geographic books to Oprah. 
Douglas Chadwick and trained grizzly bear, Tank, snarl for the camera. (Photo: COURTESY PHOTO/JOEL SARTORE) 
In conjunction with the opening, biologist and nationally acclaimed author Douglas Chadwick speaks at 2:30 p.m. In his lecture, titled “Celebration of Big Wild Lives in Big Wild Country,” Chadwick talks about the coexistence between humans and the wild communities inhabiting the lands where they live, including how mankind protects and connects to nature. 
Chadwick earned his degrees at the University of Washington and the University of Montana. His research has taken him all over the world, and he has consulted on wildlife films, videos and exhibits for various museums. A regular contributor to National Geographic magazine, Chadwick also has written 11 books, including one book for children. 
The Crown of the Continent exhibition’s sponsor is the James M. and Frances M. Wylder Foundation. 
No registration is required for any of these activities. Museum admission is $9 for adults, $7 for seniors and veterans, $4 for students and free for children younger than 5 and active military members and their families with valid I.D. 
For more information on the opening and a full list of events and activities associated with it, visit the C.M. Russell Museum’s website at www.cmrussell.org or call 727-8787. 
The exhibition closes January 18, 2016. THE ESSENTIALS
